resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
romainfrancois commented on pull request #3714: ARROW-4638: [R] install instructions using brew
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3714
 
 
   This simplifies installation of the package on macOS, thanks to @jeroen. 
   
   `brew` installs arrow 0.12 at the moment though, so we'd need to make sure not using newer features, but this makes it easier for users to try the R package. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------

romainfrancois commented on issue #3714: ARROW-4638: [R] install instructions using brew
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3714#issuecomment-465600963
 
 
   Maybe we could add a macOS / R job that would install the C++ lib from brew ?

xhochy commented on issue #3714: ARROW-4638: [R] install instructions using brew
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3714#issuecomment-466010022
 
 
   > Maybe we could add a macOS / R job that would install the C++ lib from brew ?
   
   Do we want to limit us in R then to only support features that were only released yet or can we make that conditional in the build? (I would prefer the second option but I'm not versed enough in R / arrow-r to understand how hard that would be.)
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.

romainfrancois commented on issue #3714: ARROW-4638: [R] install instructions using brew
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3714#issuecomment-466020342
 
 
   I have exchanged with @jeroen and we can do 
   
   ```
   brew install apache-arrow --HEAD
   ```
   
   maybe I should have that in the documentation instead. 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the

users@infra.apache.org

romainfrancois commented on issue #3714: ARROW-4638: [R] install instructions using brew
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3714#issuecomment-466021182
 
 
   There is a lot of feature dept in the R package anyway, so catching up with the released version of the C++ lib is not particularly a problem at the moment I think. 
   
   That however make it easier for users and other 📦 developers if we only depend on released arrow, ping @javierluraschi 
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

jeroen commented on issue #3714: ARROW-4638: [R] install instructions using brew
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3714#issuecomment-466022128
 
 
   Note though that `brew install apache-arrow --HEAD` involves compiling from source, which requires a properly setup xcode, python etc. 
   
   On the other hand `brew install apache-arrow` installs precompiled binaries from homebrew, which is much easier and more reliable for most regular users.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

jeroen commented on issue #3714: ARROW-4638: [R] install instructions using brew
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3714#issuecomment-466022128
 
 
   Note though that `brew install apache-arrow --HEAD` makes homebrew compile libarrow from source on the user machine, which requires a properly setup xcode, python etc. There is a lot that can go wrong.
   
   On the other hand `brew install apache-arrow` installs precompiled binaries from homebrew, which always works. This is much easier and more reliable for most regular users.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.
 
For queries about this service, please contact Infrastructure at:
users@infra.apache.org

   Note that `brew install apache-arrow --HEAD` makes homebrew compile libarrow from source on the user machine, which requires a properly setup xcode, python etc. There is a lot that can go wrong.
   
   On the other hand `brew install apache-arrow` installs precompiled binaries from homebrew, which always works. This is much easier and more reliable for most regular users.

   Note that `brew install apache-arrow --HEAD` makes homebrew compile libarrow from source on the user machine, which requires a properly setup xcode, python etc. There is a lot that can go wrong.
   
   On the other hand `brew install apache-arrow` installs precompiled libarrow binaries from homebrew, which always works. This is much easier and more reliable for most regular users.

xhochy commented on issue #3714: ARROW-4638: [R] install instructions using brew
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/3714#issuecomment-466027578
 
 
   > Note that `brew install apache-arrow --HEAD` makes homebrew compile libarrow from source on the user machine, which requires a properly setup xcode, python etc. There is a lot that can go wrong.
   
   I've opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-4649 to have a nightly test that checks that the homebrew formula still works. Would be good if someone could pick this up, I'm happy to give helping advice on how to achieve that.
   
   > There is a lot of feature dept in the R package anyway, so catching up with the released version of the C++ lib is not particularly a problem at the moment I think.
   
   I hope that this becomes a problems soon ;) We have a lot of cool things R folks should not miss out on.
 
----------------------------------------------------------------
This is an automated message from the Apache Git Service.
To respond to the message, please log on GitHub and use the
URL above to go to the specific comment.

users@infra.apache.org

   I've opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-4649 to have a nightly test that checks that the homebrew formula still works. Would be good if someone could pick this up, I'm happy to give helping advice on how to achieve that.
   
   > There is a lot of feature debt in the R package anyway, so catching up with the released version of the C++ lib is not particularly a problem at the moment I think.
